question: Why is moving water in a river considered a renewable resource?

content.source_1: The hydrologic cycle, powered by solar energy, continually evaporates water, forms clouds, and returns precipitation to land, sending water back into rivers after it has flowed to the ocean.
content.source_2: A resource is considered renewable when natural Earth processes replenish it on human timescales so it can be used repeatedly without being depleted.
content.source_3: River discharge is part of this cycle: precipitation, snowmelt, and groundwater return flow repeatedly supply water to river channels over time.
content.source_4: Across many regions, long-term river flows have declined and some reaches periodically run dry because withdrawals and warming-driven aridity have exceeded natural replenishment for years or decades (e.g., stretches of the Colorado and Yellow Rivers, and the Indus delta).
content.source_5: When the rate of use persistently exceeds the rate of natural replenishment on human timescales, the resource in question is not renewable under those conditions.
content.source_6: Shrinking mountain snowpacks and glaciers in numerous basins have reduced the dry-season meltwater that historically sustained downstream river flow for people and hydropower.

answer: can be recycled by nature over time
